title: Question 219

children: A 46-year-old man is evaluated in the emergency department because of a 1-day history of nausea, vomiting, and confusion. He has depression, for which fluoxetine was initiated 17 days ago.
On physical examination, blood pressure is 138/78 mm Hg without orthostatic changes. Other than confusion, the remainder of the physical examination is normal.

) is indicated. This patient's presentation is consistent with syndrome of inappropriate antidiuretic hormone secretion (SIADH), likely resulting from his recently started antidepressant medication. This diagnosis is based on a low serum osmolality and a urine osmolality that is inappropriately high relative to serum osmolality without evidence of hypovolemia. Although free water restriction is the recommended therapy for asymptomatic patients with SIADH, hypertonic saline is used to treat symptomatic patients. A typical goal for treating symptomatic hyponatremia is to increase the serum sodium level to approximately 120 mEq/L (120 mmol/L). Evidence suggests that an increase in the serum sodium level by approximately 4 to 6 mEq/L (4-6 mmol/L) over the first 24 hours is sufficient in symptomatic patients. If the extracellular fluid osmolality rapidly normalizes in a patient with chronic hyponatremia, neuronal cell shrinkage may occur and can precipitate osmotic demyelination syndrome.
